GuideTitle: Wash Your Hands for IV Treatment

steps.title: Step 1: Get Started with Soap and Water

substeps.title: Wet your hands
substeps.description: Wet your hands thoroughly under running water.

substeps.title: Apply soap
substeps.description: Dispense enough soap to cover all hand surfaces.
substeps.moreInfo: Use liquid soap if possible. Bar soap can carry bacteria.

substeps.title: Palm to palm
substeps.description: Rub your hands together, palm to palm, in a circular motion.

steps.title: Step 2: Clean Every Part of Your Hands

substeps.title: Backs of hands
substeps.description: Rub the back of each hand with the opposite palm, fingers interlaced.

substeps.title: Between fingers
substeps.description: Rub your hands with fingers interlaced, palm to palm.

substeps.title: Knuckles
substeps.description: Rub your knuckles with fingers locked together.

substeps.title: Thumbs
substeps.moreInfo: Thumbs are often missed — give them extra attention.
substeps.description: Rotate each thumb inside the opposite palm.

substeps.title: Fingertips
substeps.description: Rub your fingertips in the opposite palm using a circular motion.
substeps.moreInfo: Fingertips carry the most germs — clean them thoroughly before handling your IV line.

substeps.title: Rinse
substeps.description: Rinse your hands thoroughly under clean, running water.

substeps.title: Dry your hands
substeps.description: Dry your hands completely with a clean paper towel.
substeps.moreInfo: Bacteria spread more easily from wet hands than dry ones.

substeps.title: Turn off the tap
substeps.description: Use the paper towel to turn off the faucet. Then throw the towel away.
substeps.moreInfo: This prevents re-contaminating your hands after cleaning.

substeps.title: Use hand sanitizer if needed
substeps.description: If you touch something unclean after washing, apply alcohol gel and rub it in until dry.
substeps.moreInfo: Sanitizer is helpful between tasks or when soap and water are not available. Only use it on visibly clean hands.
